introduction.p: If you simultaneously press two piano keys, you will hear loudness of sound varying with some period. This periodic varying sound is called beats. This is illustrated in . The phenomenon is not restricted to sound waves, but can be observed when two waves of slightly different frequencies strike a detector.

figure.caption: We feel beats in the sound when the loudness of the sound varies periodically with time.

introduction.p:
For simplicity, consider two waves \psi_1 and \psi_2 of different angular frequencies \omega_1 and \omega_2 and with the same amplitude A meeting at the origin. Suppose, the waves at the origin are causing by the following vibrations.
\amp \psi_1(0,t) = A\cos(\omega_1 t), \amp \psi_2(0,t) = A\cos(\omega_2 t).
By the superposition principle, the net wave at the origin will be
\psi = \psi_1 + \psi_2 = A\left[ \cos(\omega_1 t) + \cos(\omega_2 t) \right].
Now, we can use the trigonometric identity
\cos A+ \cos B = 2\cos\left(\frac{A-B}{2}\right)\cos\left(\frac{A+B}{2}\right).
to rewrite the net wave at the origin as
\psi = \left\{ 2A\cos\left[ \left( \frac{\omega_1-\omega_2}{2}\right) t\right] \right\} \cos\left[\left(\frac{\omega_1+\omega_2}{2}\right) t\right]
The result is a net vibration at the average frequency with slowly varying amplitude, the quantity within the curly braces, \{\}. The amplitude of the wave also varies periodically - we say that the two waves are beating on each other.

Although, two waves of any frequencis can beat with each other, the pronounced beating phenomenon in sound waves we experience in music, happen when two frequencies are close to each other. Therefore, let us write \omega_1 and \omega_2 as
\amp \omega_1 = \omega_0 -\frac{\Delta\omega}{2}, \amp \omega_2 = \omega_0 +\frac{\Delta\omega}{2}.
Here, \omega_0 is their average frequency and \Delta\omega is the difference between the frequencies. Let us write this wave function in the terms of the average frequency \omega_0 and the difference \Delta\omega of the frequencies.
\psi = \left\{ 2A \cos\left( \frac{\Delta\omega }{2} t\right) \right\} \cos\left( \omega_0 t\right)
The net vibration consists of fast oscillations at the average frequency \omega_0 modulated by a slowly varying cosine as shown in .

figure.caption: The beats as a result of superposition of two vibrations. The plot was made with f_1 = 261.63 Hz and f_2 = 277.18 Hz, corresponding to C_4 and C_4^\#/D_4^b musical notes. The upper graph is the signal at frequency f_1, the middle at frequency f_2 and the bottom graph is the sum of the two. The peaks and troughs of the beats are separated by one beat period as shown.

introduction.p: The amplitude of the fast oscillations is not constant in time but rather varies between -2A and 2A.

The largest amplitude oscillations occur at the peak and trough of the slowly varying modulation \cos\left( \frac{\Delta\omega}{2}t\right). If the working frequencies are in the audible range, then the peaks and troughs of the slowly varying modulation corresponds to the loudest sound while the sound is faintest when the modulation function is smallest. Thus, sound from two sources of nearby frequencies appear to go loud and soft periodically - the loud sounds are called beats.

Since both the troughs and peaks of \cos\left( \frac{\Delta\omega}{2}t\right) correspond to the loudest sound, there are two beats in one period of this function. Therefore, the beat period is the half of the period of the modulating function \cos\left( \frac{\Delta\omega}{2}t\right).
T_{beat}= \frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{2\pi}{\Delta\omega/2}\right)=\frac{2\pi}{\Delta\omega}.
Therefore, the beat frequency is the difference in frequencies of the two component vibrations:
\omega_{beat}= \Delta\omega=\left| \omega_1-\omega_2\right|.
By setting \omega = 2\pi f, we can write this relation for the beat frequency.
\text{Beat frequency: }\ \ f_{\text{beat}}= \left| f_1-f_2\right|.

exercise.title: Using Beats to Tune a Piano

statement.p: The beat phenomenon is very sensitive for detecting the deviation of sound from a pitch. This helps piano tuners as well as members of orchestra to adjust their musical instruments. When an instrument key and a standard reference for that key do not produce any beats, then the two are said to be in tune.

Suppose that a piano key is supposed to be 256\text{ Hz}, but it is out of tune. When a tuning fork of 256\text{ Hz} is sounded at the same time as the key, one hears a beat of 2\text{ Hz} at a lower pitch than the pitch of the tuning fork.
(a) (i) By how much is the piano key out of tune? (ii) What is the fundamental frequency of the piano string that the key strikes?
(b) Should you tighten or loosen the string to tune in the piano key? Why?

hint.p: (a) Use the beat frequency formula. (b) What happens to speed of the wave when tension of the string is increased and how does that impact the fundamental frequency?

solution.title: (a)
solution.p:
(a) (i) and (ii): Using the beat frequency formula we find that the frequency of the piano key is off by the beat frequency 2\text{ Hz}. Since the average frequency heard is lower than 256\text{ Hz}, the piano key is actually producing at a lower frequency than 256\text{ Hz}. Therefore, the fundamental frequency of the string corresponding to the key is
f = f_\text{tuning fork} - f_\text{beat} = 256-2=254\text{ Hz}.

solution.title: (b)
solution.p: Speed of wave on a string is v=\sqrt{T/\mu}. Therefore, increasing tension increases speed, and from f = v/\lambda, that would mean will increase frequency. We want to increase frequency of the string vibration from 254\text{ Hz} to 256\text{ Hz}. Therefore, we should tighten the string to tune the piano.

exercise.title: How Much to Tighten a Piano String to Tune Piano?

statement.p: A piano key of 512\text{ Hz} is producing 500 Hz sound.
(a) What will be the beat frequency if it is checked against a violin producing 520\text{ Hz}?
(b) By what percentage should the tension of the wire be adjusted so that the pitch is adjusted to 512\text{ Hz}? Assume insignificant change in mass per unit length while tightening.

hint.p: (a) Use the beat frequency formula. (b) Use v=\sqrt{T/\mu} and f\lambda=v with fixed \lambda and \mu and determine \Delta T/T for corresponding \Delta f/f.

solution.title: (a)
solution.p:
Using the beat frequency formula, we immediately get the answer.
f_\text{beat} = 520-500 = 20\text{ Hz}.

solution.title: (b)
solution.p:
From v=\sqrt{T/\mu} and f\lambda=v we get
T = (\mu \lambda^2) f^2.
Here \mu \lambda^2 is fixed. You can use Calculus to get dT/df, but here I will just say that, let tension be T+\Delta T when frequency is f+\Delta f. Writing a for the fixed part.
T + \Delta T = a (f + \Delta f)^2 = a f^2 + 2 a f \Delta f + a (\Delta f)^2.
We drop the last term, which will be small compared to the other terms. This gives
T + \Delta T \approx a f^2 + 2 a f \Delta f .
Using Eq. we get
\Delta T = 2 a f \Delta f.
Divide this by T to get
\frac{\Delta T}{ T } = 2 \frac{\Delta f}{f}.
Now, using the numerical values we obtain
\frac{\Delta T}{ T } = 2\times \frac{12}{500} = 0.048 = 4.8%.
